1-4-1.SDG_GOAL: 1. End poverty in all its forms everywhere
1-4-1.SDG_TARGET: 1.4:  By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance
1-4-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 1.4.1: Proportion of population living in households with access to basic services
1-4-1.SDG_SERIES_DESCR: The indicator provides information on access to both basis sanitation services and basic drinking water services
1-4-1.SDG_RELATED_INDICATORS:
6.1.1 Proportion of population using safely managed drinking water services

6.2.1 Proportion of population using (a) safely managed sanitation services and (b) a hand-washing facility with soap and water
1-4-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition

The proportion of households which have access to basic drinking water and sanitation service. Access to basic services implies that sufficient and affordable service is reliably available with adequate quality.

Concepts

Households with access to piped water, communal taps, protected boreholes and wells within 1 km from their home are consider to have access to an improved source of water.

Households with access to flush toilets and pit latrines that are not shared with other households are consider to have access to an improved sanitation services.
1-4-1.SOURCE_TYPE:
The Inter-Censal Demographic Survey (ICDS) (2017) is a household based survey, which is conducted five years after a decennial census. It covers the whole country (all the ten provinces).

The aim of the survey is to gather information on population size and structure, population Distribution, migration, household characteristics, education, activity and labour force as well as mortality and orphanhood.
1-4-1.COLL_METHOD:
Sample design

The sample design for the 2017 ICDS is two stages, with Enumeration Areas (EAs) as the first stage and households as the second stage sampling units. In total, 400 EAs were selected with probability proportional to size (PPS), the measure of size being the number of households enumerated in the 2012 population census. The 2017 ICDS sample was stratified by province and urban/rural.

Sample size

A representative probability sample of 11,200 private households was selected for 2017 ICDS. The ICDS was designed to produce estimates at national and provincial levels as well as for rural and urban areas.

Questionnaire design

The principal instrument used to collect primary data was the structured questionnaire uploaded on tablet which was administered through face-to-face interviews.

Type of interview

Face to face Interviews were conducted with household heads. For the first time, the Zimbabwe ICDS used Computer Assisted Personal Interviews (CAPI) using mobiles devices

Duration of fieldwork

Fieldwork took place on 18-22 August 2017.

Interviewer training

Training of trainers was conducted 3-4 August 2017. Training of field staff for the main survey was conducted from 7-11 August 2017.

Response rate

The response rate was 92.2 %.
1-4-1.FREQ_COLL: The survey is conducted every tenth year.
1-4-1.INST_MANDATE: The data collection and production of statistics for this indicator adhere to the census and Statistics Act of Zimbabwe.
1-4-1.RATIONALE: Providing access to basic services such as safe drinking water and sanitation facilities helps to improve the quality of life of the poor. The lack of basic services provision and the lack of empowerment and involvement of local governments in basic service delivery undermine the economic growth and quality of life in any community.
1-4-1.REC_USE_LIM: Level of permissible sampling error allowed for the estimates was 10%.
1-4-1.DATA_COMP: Number of households with access to service divided by total number of households multiplied by 100
1-4-1.DATA_VALIDATION:
Steps undertaken to achieve this included field questionnaire editing, pre-programmed data entry template with in-built skipping and validation checks.

Data was merged into one data set by system developers who then analyzed and produced required tables using CSPro and SAS.
1-4-1.DOC_METHOD: Global metadata prepared by custodian agencies are available for the indicator.
1-4-1.QUALITY_MGMNT: ZIMSTAT follows the recommendations of the UN Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics, the African Charter on Statistics and UN National Quality Assurance Framework.
1-4-1.COVERAGE:
The ICDS is conducted every tenth year. The first post-independence survey was in 1987, the second in 1997 and the third in 2007.

Data is disaggregated by distance to water source, type of service, province and urban/rural.
1-4-1.OTHER_DOC:
The publication incl. detailed methodology can be found here:

https://zimstat.co.zw/wp-content/uploads/publications/Population/population/ICDS_2017.pdf

2-2-1.SDG_TARGET: 2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons
2-2-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 2.2.1 Proportion of children moderately or severely stunted
2-2-1.SDG_RELATED_INDICATORS: 2.2.2 Prevalence of malnutrition (weight for height >+2 or <-2 standard deviation from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards) among children under 5 years of age, by type (wasting and overweight)
2-2-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition

The percentage of children under five years old whose height for age are less than minus two standard deviations from the median of the reference population ages 0–59 months.

Concepts

Height for age is a measure of linear growth. Children whose height for age is more than two standard deviation below the median (WHO standards) are considered short for their age and are classified as moderately or severely stunted. Stunting or chronic malnutrition, is the result of failure to receive adequate nutrition in early life over an extended period.
2-2-1.CLASS_SYSTEM: The nutritional status of children in the survey population was compared with the 2006 WHO Child Growth Standards (WHO, 2006)
2-2-1.SOURCE_TYPE:
Different surveys provide data at different years for this indicator

Demographic Health Survey (DHS):

The primary objective of the survey is to provide current demographic and health information for use by policymakers, planners, researchers and programme managers. The survey will thus assist policy makers and programme managers in evaluating and designing programmes and strategies for improving the health of the country’s population.

Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS):

The survey is designed to provide high quality data for assessing the situation of children, adolescents, women and households in Zimbabwe.
2-2-1.COLL_METHOD:
DHS

MICS

Sample design

The 2012 Zimbabwe Population Census was used as the sampling frame for the 2015 ZDHS.

Sample design

Sample size

The 2015 DHS sample was selected with a stratified, two-stage cluster design. The 2015 DHS sample included 400 enumeration areas: 166 in urban areas and 234 in rural areas. A representative sample of 11,196 households was selected for the 2015 DHS.

Sample size

A total of 462 clusters and 12,012 households were selected at the national level.

Questionnaire design

Four questionnaires were used for the 2015 DHS: the Household Questionnaire, the Woman’s Questionnaire, the Man’s Questionnaire, and the Biomarker Questionnaire.

Women age 15-49 and men age 15-54 who were either permanent residents of the selected households or visitors who stayed in the household the night before the survey were eligible for interviewing.

Questionnaire design

Six questionnaires were used in the survey, i.e. (i) Household questionnaire, (ii) Water and Sanitation, (iii) Individual Men/Women, (v) Children Age 5-17 yrs and (vi) Children under 5 yrs.

Type of interview

Household based interview using Computer Assisted Personal Interviews (CAPI), with the option to choose English, Shona, or Ndebele for each questionnaire.

Type of interview

Household based interview using Computer Assisted Personal Interviews (CAPI).

Duration of fieldwork

Fieldwork took place over a 6-month period from July 6 to December 20, 2015.

Duration of fieldwork

Fieldwork began in January 2019 and was concluded in April 2019.

Interviewer training

Training was done in 25 days and included lectures on interviewing techniques and field procedures, a detailed review of the questionnaire content, and mock interviews between participants in the classroom. The trainees also had 3 days of field practice.

Interviewer training

Training was done in 35 days and included lectures on interviewing techniques and questionnaire content, mock interviews to gain practical experience. The trainees also had 4 days of field practice

Response rate

A total of 10,534 households were successfully interviewed, yielding a response rate of 99 percent.

Response rate

The household response rate was 98 % while the Water Quality Testing yielded a response rate of 95.6%. Overall response rate of 92.8; 87.1; 96.1 and 96.3 percent were yielded for the individual interviews of women, men, under age 5 and children age 5-17 years, respectively.
2-2-1.FREQ_COLL:
DHS: Every 5 years

MICS: Next data collection is planned for 2024.
2-2-1.REL_CAL_POLICY:
DHS: Every 5 years

MICS: Preliminary results are normally produced 02 months after data collection, while the final results should be available after -04 months
2-2-1.INST_MANDATE: The data collection and production of statistics for this indicator adhere to the census and Statistics Act of Zimbabwe.
2-2-1.RATIONALE: Children’s nutrition status reflects their overall health. When children have access to an adequate food supply, are not exposed to repeated illness, and are well cared for, they reach their growth potential and are considered well nourished.
2-2-1.DATA_COMP:
w = (c /b) * 100

Where C denotes the number of children under age five that fall below minus two standard deviations from the median height for age of the 2006 WHO Child Growth Standards (moderate and severe) and B denotes the total number of children under age five that were weighted.
2-2-1.DATA_VALIDATION:
DHS: CSPro was used for data editing, weighting, cleaning, and tabulation. In ZIMSTAT’s central office, data received from the supervisor’s tablets were registered and checked for inconsistencies and outliers. Data editing and cleaning included structure and internal consistency checks to ensure the completeness of work in the field. Any anomalies were communicated to the respective team through the technical team and the team supervisor. The corrected results were then re-sent to the central office.

MICS: During data collection, the field supervisor is responsible for reviewing paper questionnaires for completeness and consistency before entering data into a tablet equipped with a data entry programme.

After the completion of data entry, data is cleaned by conducting internal tests for outlier answers and comprehensive audit rules. SPSS Version 24 was used to analyse data and Model syntax and tabulation plan developed by UNICEF were customized and used for this purpose.
2-2-1.DOC_METHOD: Global metadata prepared by custodian agencies are available for the indicator.
2-2-1.QUALITY_MGMNT: ZIMSTAT follows the recommendations of the UN Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics, the African Charter on Statistics and UN National Quality Assurance Framework.
2-2-1.QUALITY_ASSURE: MICS: Data were received at the ZIMSTAT head office via the File Transfer Protocol (FTP) integrated into the management application on the supervisor’s tablets. Whenever logistically possible, synchronization was daily. The central office system developers installed application updates to field staff manually.
2-2-1.COVERAGE:
DHS: The survey is conducted since 1988. The survey is conducted approximately every 5 years.

The indicator is available age in months, sex, birth interval in months, size at birth, mother’s interview status, mother’s nutritional status.

MICS: The indicator is available since 2014. The survey is conducted every 5 years.

The indicator is available by geographical location, sex, age, religion, education of mother, wealth quantile and functional difficulty of mother.

2-2-2.SDG_TARGET: 2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons
2-2-2.SDG_INDICATOR: 2.2.2 Prevalence of malnutrition (weight for height >+2 or <-2 standard deviation from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards) among children under 5 years of age, by type (wasting and overweight)
2-2-2.SDG_SERIES_DESCR: The indicator shows both the proportion of children moderately or severely wasted and the proportion of children moderately or severely overweight
2-2-2.SDG_RELATED_INDICATORS: 2.2.1 Prevalence of stunting (height for age <-2 standard deviation from the median of the World Health Organization (WHO) Child Growth Standards) among children under 5 years of age
2-2-2.STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition

The percentage of children under five years old whose weight for height are more than two standard deviations below (wasting) or above (overweight) the median reference population ages 0–59 months.

Concepts

Wasting: Weight-for-height can be used to assess wasting and overweight status. Children whose weight-for-height is more than two standard deviations below the median of the reference population are classified as moderately or severely wasted. Those who fall more than three standard deviations below the median are classified as severely wasted.

Wasting is usually the result of poor nutrient intake or disease. The prevalence of wasting may shift seasonally in response to changes in the availability of food and/or disease prevalence.

Overweight: Children whose weight-for-height is more than two standard deviations above the median reference population are classified as moderately or severely overweight.
2-2-2.CLASS_SYSTEM: The nutritional status of children in the survey population was compared with the 2006 WHO Child Growth Standards (WHO, 2006)
2-2-2.SOURCE_TYPE:
Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS).

The survey is designed to provide high quality data for assessing the situation of children, adolescents, women and households in Zimbabwe.
2-2-2.COLL_METHOD:
Sample design

Sample size

A total of 462 clusters and 12,012 households were selected at the national level.

Questionnaire design

Six questionnaires were used in the survey, i.e. (i) Household questionnaire, (ii) Water and Sanitation, (iii) Individual Men/Women, (v) Children Age 5-17 yrs and (vi) Children under 5 yrs.

Type of interview

Household based interview using Computer Assisted Personal Interviews (CAPI).

Duration of fieldwork

Fieldwork began in January 2019 and was concluded in April 2019.

Interviewer training

Training was done in 35 days and included lectures on interviewing techniques and questionnaire content, mock interviews to gain practical experience. The trainees also had 4 days of field practice

Response rate

The household response rate was 98 % while the Water Quality Testing yielded a response rate of 95.6%. Overall response rate of 92.8 ; 87.1; 96.1 and 96.3 percent were yielded for the individual interviews of women, men, under 5s and children age 5-17 years , respectively.
2-2-2.REL_CAL_POLICY: Preliminary results are normally produced 02 months after data collection, while the final results should be available after -04 months.
2-2-2.INST_MANDATE: The data collection and production of statistics for this indicator adhere to the census and Statistics Act of Zimbabwe.
2-2-2.RATIONALE: Children’s nutrition status reflects their overall health. When children have access to an adequate food supply, are not exposed to repeated illness, and are well cared for, they reach their growth potential and are considered well nourished.
2-2-2.DATA_COMP:
Wasting: = (c /b) * 100

Where C denotes the number of children under age five that fall below minus two standard deviations from the median weight for height of the 2006 WHO Child Growth Standards (moderate and severe) and B denotes the total number of children under age five that were weighted.

Overweight: = (c /b) * 100

Where C denotes the number of children under age five who are more than two standard deviations above from the median weight for height of the 2006 WHO Child Growth Standards (moderate and severe) and B denotes the total number of children under age five that were weighted.
2-2-2.DATA_VALIDATION:
During data collection, the field supervisor is responsible for reviewing paper questionnaires for completeness and consistency before entering data into a tablet equipped with a data entry programme.

After the completion of data entry, data is cleaned by conducting internal tests for outlier answers and comprehensive audit rules. SPSS Version 24 was used to analyse data and Model syntax and tabulation plan developed by UNICEF were customized and used for this purpose.
2-2-2.DOC_METHOD: Global metadata prepared by custodian agencies are available for the indicator.
2-2-2.QUALITY_MGMNT: ZIMSTAT follows the recommendations of the UN Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics, the African Charter on Statistics and UN National Quality Assurance Framework.
2-2-2.QUALITY_ASSURE: Data were received at the ZIMSTAT head office via the File Transfer Protocol (FTP) integrated into the management application on the supervisor’s tablets. Whenever logistically possible, synchronization was daily. The central office system developers installed application updates to field staff manually.
2-2-2.COVERAGE:
The indicator is available since 2014. The survey is conducted every 5 years.

The indicator is available by geographical location, sex, age, religion, education of mother, wealth quantile and functional difficulty of mother.

3-1-1.SDG_GOAL: 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-1-1.SDG_TARGET: 3.1: By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births
3-1-1.SDG_RELATED_INDICATORS:
3.1.2: Proportion of births attended by skilled health personnel

3.7.1: Proportion of women of reproductive age (aged 15–49 years) who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods

3.7.2: Adolescent birth rate (aged 10–14 years; aged 15–19 years) per 1,000 women in that age group
3-1-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition

Maternal mortality ratio is defined as deaths during pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days (MICS) (or 2 months DHS) of termination excluding accidents and acts of violence, per 100,000 live births.

Concepts

Maternal death: The death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days (MICS and ICDS) (or 2 months DHS) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of the pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management (from direct or indirect obstetric death), but not from accidental or incidental causes.

3-1-1.COMPARABILITY:
DHS and MICS/ICDS use different definition of maternal mortality as DHS’ questionnaire refer to deaths within 2 months following a birth rather than 42 days following a birth.

ICDS asks if a death to a female age 15-49 years had occurred in the household within the last 12 months, while MICS and DHS ask about occurrence within the past 7 years.

3-1-2.SDG_GOAL: 3. Ensure Good Health and Well Being for All

3-1-2.SDG_RELATED_INDICATORS: Related to Target 3.1 on reducing maternal mortality, 3.2 on reducing neonatal mortality and 3.8 on achieving universal health coverage (coverage of essential health services)
3-1-2.STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition

The proportion of total live births in a period that are attended by a skilled birth attendant trained in providing lifesaving obstetric care.

Concepts

Women age 15-49 years with a live birth in the last 2 years for MICS and in the last 5 years for DHS.

Skilled birth attendant include doctor, nurse and midwife
3-1-2.CLASS_SYSTEM: The indicator is calculated in line with WHO Recommendations on Antenatal Care for a Positive Pregnancy Experience, WHO Press 2016

Different surveys provide data at different years for this indicator

3-1-2.INST_MANDATE: The data collection and production of statistics for this indicator adhere to the census and Statistics Act of Zimbabwe.
3-1-2.RATIONALE:
Antenatal care can be used to inform women and families about risks and symptoms in pregnancy and about the risks of labour and delivery, and therefore it may provide the route for ensuring that pregnant women do, in practice deliver with the assistance of a skilled health provider. Antenatal visits also provide the opportunity to supply information on birth spacing, which is recognized as an important factor in improving infant survival.

It is of crucial importance for the pregnant women to start attending antenatal care visits as early as in pregnancy as possible and ideally have the first visit during the first trimester to prevent and detect pregnancy conditions that could affect both the women and her baby.
3-1-2.DATA_COMP: Calculated as the number of births attended by skilled health personnel (doctors, nurses or midwives) divided by the total number of births in the same period and multiplied by 100.
3-1-2.DATA_VALIDATION:
DHS: CSPro was used for data editing, weighting, cleaning, and tabulation. In ZIMSTAT’s central office, data received from the supervisor’s tablets were registered and checked for inconsistencies and outliers. Data editing and cleaning included structure and internal consistency checks to ensure the completeness of work in the field. Any anomalies were communicated to the respective team through the technical team and the team supervisor. The corrected results were then re-sent to the central office.

MICS: During data collection, the field supervisor is responsible for reviewing paper questionnaires for completeness and consistency before entering data into a tablet equipped with a data entry programme.

After the completion of data entry, data is cleaned by conducting internal tests for outlier answers and comprehensive audit rules. SPSS Version 24 was used to analyse data and Model syntax and tabulation plan developed by UNICEF were customized and used for this purpose.

3-2-1.SDG_GOAL: 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-2-1.SDG_TARGET: 3.2: By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under‑5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births
3-2-1.SDG_SERIES_DESCR: The indicator provides information on under-five mortality rate
3-2-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition

Under-five mortality is a combination of infant and child mortality and is defined as the number of children dying before they celebrate their fifth birthday out of 1,000 live births.

Concepts

Mortality: the number of deaths that occur in a population.

Under-five Mortality: death between birth and fifth birthday
3-2-1.SOURCE_TYPE:
Different surveys provide data at different years for this indicator

Demographic Health Survey (DHS):

The primary objective of the survey is to provide current demographic and health information for use by policymakers, planners, researchers and programme managers. The survey will thus assist policy makers and programme managers in evaluating and designing programmes and strategies for improving the health of the country’s population.

Inter-Censal Demographic Survey (ICDS):

The Inter-Censal Demographic Survey (ICDS) (2017) is a household based survey, which is conducted five years after a decennial census. It covers the whole country (all the ten provinces).

The aim of the survey is to gather information on population size and structure, population Distribution, migration, household characteristics, education, activity and labour force as well as mortality and orphanhood.

Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS):

The survey is designed to provide high quality data for assessing the situation of children, adolescents, women and households in Zimbabwe

ICDS

MICS

Sample design

The 2012 Zimbabwe Population Census was used as the sampling frame for the 2015 ZDHS.

Sample design

The sample design for the 2017 ICDS is two stages, with Enumeration Areas (EAs) as the first stage and households as the second stage sampling units. In total, 400 EAs were selected with probability proportional to size (PPS), the measure of size being the number of households enumerated in the 2012 population census. The 2017 ICDS sample was stratified by province and urban/rural.

Sample design

Sample size

The 2015 DHS sample was selected with a stratified, two-stage cluster design. The 2015 DHS sample included 400 enumeration areas: 166 in urban areas and 234 in rural areas. A representative sample of 11,196 households was selected for the 2015 DHS.

Sample size

Sample size

Questionnaire design

Four questionnaires were used for the 2015 DHS: the Household Questionnaire, the Woman’s Questionnaire, the Man’s Questionnaire, and the Biomarker Questionnaire.

Women age 15-49 and men age 15-54 who were either permanent residents of the selected households or visitors who stayed in the household the night before the survey were eligible for interviewing.

Questionnaire design

The principal instrument used to collect primary data was the structured questionnaire uploaded on tablet which was administered through face-to-face interviews.

The questionnaire asks whether every birth of a child in the household has been registered.

Questionnaire design

Mortality rates are calculated from information collected in the birth histories of the Women’s Questionnaires. 3-2-1.RATIONALE: Information on infant and child mortality is relevant to a demographic assessment of the population, and is an important indicator of the country’s socioeconomic development and quality life. This information can help identify children who may be at greater risk of death and can lead to strategies to reduce the risks.
3-2-1.REC_USE_LIM:
In the absence of complete civil registration of birth and death, methods have been developed for the estimation of mortality using an indirect approach. These methods utilise information on children ever born and those surviving. This provides information to the estimation of levels of child mortality.

3-7-1.SDG_TARGET: 3.1: By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births
3-7-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 3.7.1 Proportion of women of reproductive age (aged 15–49 years) who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods
3-7-1.SDG_RELATED_INDICATORS:
This indicator is linked to Target 3.8 (Achieve universal health coverage) because the provision of family planning information and methods to all individuals who want to prevent pregnancy is an important component of achieving universal health coverage.

This indicator is also linked to Target 5.6 (Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights) because meeting the demand for family planning is facilitated by increasing access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, and also improves sexual and reproductive health and the ability to exercise reproductive rights.
3-7-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition

Concepts

Contraceptive methods: Include female sterilisation, male sterilisation, pill, IUCD, injectables, implants, male condom, female condom, emergency contraception, and lactational amenorrhoea method (LAM), and other modern methods

Unmet need for family planning: Proportion of women who (1) are not pregnant and not postpartum amenorrhoeic and are considered fecund and want to postpone their next birth for 2 or more years or stop childbearing altogether but are not using a contraceptive method, or (2) have a mistimed or unwanted current pregnancy, or (3) are postpartum amenorrhoeic and their last birth in the last 2 years was mistimed or unwanted.
3-7-1.SOURCE_TYPE:

3-7-1.RATIONALE: The proportion of demand for family planning satisfied with modern methods is useful in assessing overall levels of coverage for family planning programmes and services. Access to and use of an effective means to prevent pregnancy helps enable women and their partners to exercise their rights to decide freely and responsibly the number and spacing of their children and to have the information, education and means to do so. Meeting demand for family planning with modern methods also contributes to maternal and child health by preventing unintended pregnancies and closely spaced pregnancies, which are at higher risk for poor obstetrical outcomes.
3-7-1.DATA_COMP: Proportion of demand satisfied by modern methods = Current contraceptive use, any modern method divided by (Unmet need + current contraceptive use, any method)

4-2-2.SDG_GOAL: 4. Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4-2-2.SDG_TARGET: 4.2: By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre‑primary education so that they are ready for primary education
4-2-2.SDG_INDICATOR: 4.2.2 Participation rate in organized learning (one year before the official primary entry age), by sex
4-2-2.SDG_RELATED_INDICATORS:
Target 1.4: By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance
Target 4.5: By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations
4-2-2.STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition

The participation rate in organized learning (one year before the official primary entry age), by sex as defined as the percentage of children in the given age range who participate in one or more organized learning programme, including programmes which offer a combination of education and care. Participation in early childhood and in primary education are both included (the adjusted net attendance ratio).

Concepts

Children age one year younger than the official primary school entry age at the beginning of the school year. The official primary school entry age in Zimbabwe is 6 years.

4-4-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition

Percentage of men and women age 15-49 years who in the last 3 months have carried out computer related activities.

Concepts

Computer related activities are as follows:

- Copying or moving a file or folder

- Using copy and paste tools to duplicate or move information within a document

-Sending e-mails with attached files such as document, picture, video

- Using basic arithmetic formulas in a spreadsheet

- Connecting and installing new devices such as a modem, camera, printer

- Finding, downloading, installing and configuring software

- Creating electronic presentations with presentation software including text, images, sound, video or charts

- Transferring files between a computer and other devices

- Wrote a computer program in any programming language
4-4-1.SOURCE_TYPE:
Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS).

The survey is designed to provide high quality data for assessing the situation of children, adolescents, women and households in Zimbabwe.
4-4-1.COLL_METHOD:
Sample design

Sample size

A total of 462 clusters and 12,012 households were selected at the national level.

Questionnaire design

Six questionnaires were used in the survey, i.e. (i) Household questionnaire, (ii) Water and Sanitation, (iii) Individual Men/Women, (v) Children Age 5-17 yrs and (vi) Children under 5 yrs.

Type of interview

Household based interview using Computer Assisted Personal Interviews (CAPI).

Duration of fieldwork

Fieldwork began in January 2019 and was concluded in April 2019.

Interviewer training

Training was done in 35 days and included lectures on interviewing techniques and questionnaire content, mock interviews to gain practical experience. The trainees also had 4 days of field practice

Response rate

The household response rate was 98 % while the Water Quality Testing yielded a response rate of 95.6%. Overall response rate of 92.8; 87.1; 96.1 and 96.3 percent were yielded for the individual interviews of women, men, under age 5 and children age 5-17 years, respectively.

4-4-1.RATIONALE: ICT skills determine the effective use of information and communication technology. The lack of such skills is a key barrier keeping people from fully benefitting from the potential of information and communication technologies.
4-4-1.DATA_COMP: In-scope who have carried out each activity in the past 3 months, regardless of where that activity took place, divided by total in-scope population, multiplied by 100.

6-1-1.SDG_TARGET: 6.1: By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all
6-1-1.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 6.1.1: Proportion of population using safely managed drinking water services
6-1-1.SDG_RELATED_INDICATORS:

6-1-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition

Percentage of household members with an improved drinking water source located on premises, whose source water was tested and free of E. coli and available when needed

Concepts

Improved drinking water sources include: piped water; tube well/ borehole; protected well or spring; rainwater collection; bottled or sachet water; tanker-truck/cart with small tank.

A water source is considered to be ‘located on premises’ if the point of collection is within the dwelling, yard, or plot.

Water free from faecal contamination has risk level of E. coli below 100 ml.

Water is not available when household members are unable to access water in sufficient quantities when water is not available from source, water is too expensive, source is not accessible and other reasons.

The DHS looks only at the source of water when calculating this indicator.

8-7-1.SDG_GOAL: 8. Promote sustained, inclusive and sustainable economic growth, full and productive employment and decent work for all
8-7-1.SDG_TARGET: 8.7 Take immediate and effective measures to eradicate forced labour, end modern slavery and human trafficking and secure the prohibition and elimination of the worst forms of child labour, including recruitment and use of child soldiers, and by 2025 end child labour in all its forms
8-7-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 8.7.1: Proportion and number of children aged 5-17 years engaged in child labour, by sex and age
8-7-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition

Proportion of children aged 5-17 years (MICS) (or 10-14 years for ICDS) engaged in economic activity and household chores at or above the age specific threshold.

Concepts

An economic activity is defined as paid or unpaid work for someone who is not a member of the household, work for a family farm or business. .

A child that performed economic activities during the last week for more than the age-specific number of hours is classified as in child labour: (i). age 5-11: 1 hour or more; (ii). age 12-14: 14 hours or more; (iii). age 15-17: 43 hours or more.

Domestic work is defined as household chores such as cooking, cleaning or caring for children, as well as collecting firewood or fetching water.

A child that performed household chores during the last week for more than the age-specific number of hours is classified as in child labour. (i). age 5-11 and age 12-14: 21 hours or more; (ii). age 15-17: No limit to number of hour.

ICDS looks only at economic activity.

The child labour module was administered for one randomly selected child age 5-17 years in each household and includes questions on the type of work a child does and the number of hours he or she is engaged in it. Data are collected on both economic activities (paid or unpaid work for someone who is not a member of the household, work for a family farm or business) and domestic work (household chores such as cooking, cleaning or caring for children, as well as collecting firewood or fetching water).

Type of interview

Face to face Interviews were conducted with household heads. For the first time, the Zimbabwe ICDS used Computer Assisted Personal Interviews (CAPI) using mobiles devices

Type of interview

Household based interview using Computer Assisted Personal Interviews (CAPI).

Duration of fieldwork

Fieldwork took place on 18-22 August 2017.

Duration of fieldwork

Fieldwork began in January 2019 and was concluded in April 2019.

Interviewer training

Training of trainers was conducted 3-4 August 2017. Training of field staff for the main survey was conducted from 7-11 August 2017.

Interviewer training

Training was done in 35 days and included lectures on interviewing techniques and questionnaire content, mock interviews to gain practical experience. The trainees also had 4 days of field practice

Response rate

The response rate was 92.2 %.

Response rate

The household response rate was 98 % while the Water Quality Testing yielded a response rate of 95.6%. Overall response rate of 92.8; 87.1; 96.1 and 96.3 percent were yielded for the individual interviews of women, men, under age 5 and children age 5-17 years, respectively.

16-9-1.SDG_GOAL: 16. Promote peaceful and inclusive societies for sustainable development, provide access to justice for all and build effective, accountable and inclusive institutions at all levels
16-9-1.SDG_TARGET: 16.9: By 2030, provide legal identity for all, including birth registration
16-9-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 16.9.1 Proportion of children under 5 years of age whose births have been registered with a civil authority, by age
16-9-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition

Proportion of children under 5 years of age whose births have been registered with a civil authority.

Concepts

Birth registration is defined as the recording of a birth with the Registrar General’s Office, which has the sole responsibility for birth registration in Zimbabwe in accordance with the Birth and Deaths Registration Act. In terms of the Act, a birth should be registered within 42 days. Parents are encouraged to register their children soon after birth, however, late registrations are also accommodated. For children born in health facilities, a birth confirmation record is required on registering a birth. For children born out of hospital, a witness is required to confirm the birth of the child.
16-9-1.SOURCE_TYPE:
Different surveys provide data at different years for this indicator

Inter-Censal Demographic Survey (ICDS):

The Inter-Censal Demographic Survey (ICDS) (2017) is a household based survey, which is conducted five years after a decennial census. It covers the whole country (all the ten provinces).

The aim of the survey is to gather information on population size and structure, population Distribution, migration, household characteristics, education, activity and labour force as well as mortality and orphanhood.

Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS):

The survey is designed to provide high quality data for assessing the situation of children, adolescents, women and households in Zimbabwe.
16-9-1.COLL_METHOD:
ICDS

MICS

Sample design

The sample design for the 2017 ICDS is two stages, with Enumeration Areas (EAs) as the first stage and households as the second stage sampling units. In total, 400 EAs were selected with probability proportional to size (PPS), the measure of size being the number of households enumerated in the 2012 population census. The 2017 ICDS sample was stratified by province and urban/rural.

Sample design

Sample size

A representative probability sample of 11,200 private households was selected for 2017 ICDS. The ICDS was designed to produce estimates at national and provincial levels as well as for rural and urban areas.

Sample size

A total of 462 clusters and 12,012 households were selected at the national level.

Questionnaire design

The principal instrument used to collect primary data was the structured questionnaire uploaded on tablet which was administered through face-to-face interviews.

The questionnaire asks whether every birth of a child in the household has been registered.

17-8-1.SDG_TARGET: 17.8: Fully operationalize the technology bank and science, technology and innovation capacity-building mechanism for least developed countries by 2017 and enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology
17-8-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 17.8.1: Proportion of individuals using the Internet
17-8-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition

Percentage of women and men who have used the internet during the last 3 months from any location.

Concepts

The Internet is a worldwide public computer network. It provides access to a number of communication services including the World Wide Web and carries e-mail, news, entertainment and data files, irrespective of the device used (not assumed to be only via a computer - it may also be by mobile telephone, tablet, PDA, games machine, digital TV etc.). Access can be via a fixed or mobile network.
17-8-1.SOURCE_TYPE:
Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS).

The survey is designed to provide high quality data for assessing the situation of children, adolescents, women and households in Zimbabwe.
17-8-1.COLL_METHOD:

A total of 462 clusters and 12,012 households were selected at the national level.

Questionnaire design

Six questionnaires were used in the survey, i.e. (i) Household questionnaire, (ii) Water and Sanitation, (iii) Individual Men/Women, (v) Children Age 5-17 yrs and (vi) Children under 5 yrs.

Type of interview

Household based interview using Computer Assisted Personal Interviews (CAPI).

Duration of fieldwork

Fieldwork began in January 2019 and was concluded in April 2019.

Training was done in 35 days and included lectures on interviewing techniques and questionnaire content, mock interviews to gain practical experience. The trainees also had 4 days of field practice

The household response rate was 98 % while the Water Quality Testing yielded a response rate of 95.6%. Overall response rate of 92.8; 87.1; 96.1 and 96.3 percent were yielded for the individual interviews of women, men, under-5s and children age 5-17 years, respectively.

17-8-1.INST_MANDATE: The data collection and production of statistics for this indicator adhere to the census and Statistics Act of Zimbabwe.
17-8-1.RATIONALE: This indicator highlights the importance of Internet use as a development enabler and helps to measure the digital divide.
17-8-1.DATA_COMP: Number of in-scope individuals using the Internet (from any location) in the last 3 months divided by the total number of in-scope individuals.
